def: {bc} to decide that a particular person or thing is the one that you want
{bc} to make a choice about what to do

dt: {bc}to make a choice about what to do {bc}{sx|decide||}

dt.t: They {it}chose to go{/it} by train.

to make a choice about what to do : decide —usually followed by to + verb

def: {bc} to choose or select (someone or something) from a group
{bc} to remove (a fruit, flower, etc.) from a plant especially by using your hand
{bc} to remove unwanted material from (something) by using your finger, a small tool, etc.

dt: {bc}to choose or select (someone or something) from a group

dt: {bc}to remove (a fruit, flower, etc.) from a plant especially by using your hand

dt.t: She {it}picked{/it} a flower for her mother.
I {it}picked{/it} some carrots and a few tomatoes.
They sell freshly {it}picked{/it} fruits and vegetables.
Our grapes are {it}picked{/it} by hand.

dt: {bc}to remove unwanted material from (something) by using your finger, a small tool, etc.

dt.t: It's considered impolite to {phrase}pick your nose{/phrase} in public.
He was sitting at the table, {phrase}picking his teeth{/phrase} with a toothpick.

lbs: always followed by an adverb or preposition
dt: {bc}to remove (something) from something by using your fingers

dt.t: {it}Pick{/it} the meat from/off the bones.

dt: {bc}to play (a guitar, banjo, etc.) by pulling the strings with your fingers or with a pick {bc}{sx|pluck||}

dt.t: She was strumming and {it}picking{/it} her guitar.

dt: {bc}to deliberately start a fight with someone

dt.t: Never {it}pick a fight{/it} you can't win.

dt: {bc}to open a lock by using something that is not the key

dt.t: He used a knife to {it}pick the lock{/it} on the front door.

dt: {bc}to choose only the best or most appropriate things or people

dt.t: As one of Hollywood's most successful actors, he's now in a position to carefully {it}pick and choose{/it} his roles.

dt: {bc}to say all of the things that are bad or wrong about (someone or something) {bc}to criticize (a person or thing) in a very detailed and usually unkind way

dt: {bc}to eat small amounts of (food) very slowly usually because you do not want to eat

dt.t: She {it}picked at{/it} a salad while I ate my steak.

dt: {bc}to pull on (something) with your fingertips or your fingernails often because you are nervous

dt: {bc}to criticize (someone or something) especially for small mistakes

dt.t: The hunters hid by the stream and waited to {it}pick off{/it} deer as they passed.

dt: {bc}to cause (a player who is standing close to a base) to be tagged out by making a quick throw

dt: {bc}to laugh at or make fun of (someone) in an unkind way

dt: {bc}to unfairly criticize (one person or group) when others also deserve to be criticized

dt.t: It's unfair to {it}pick on{/it} teachers for the problems in our schools when politicians are equally to blame.

dt: {bc}to choose or select (the best or most appropriate person or thing) from a group

dt: {bc}to look at (a group of objects or an amount of material) in order to choose the best ones or to remove pieces you do not want

dt: {bc}to steal money or objects from someone's pockets or purse

dt.t: One of the boys distracted her while the other {it}picked her pocket{/it}.

dt: {bc}to study and criticize all of the parts of (someone or something)

dt.t: The media {it}picked{/it} his personal life {it}to pieces{/it}.
Her ideas were {it}picked to shreds{/it} by her coworkers.

dt: {bc}to remove all the material that covers something

dt.t: The birds {it}picked{/it} the bones {it}clean{/it}. = The bones were {it}picked clean{/it} by the birds.

dt: {bc}to lift (someone or something) from the ground or a low surface

dt: {bc}to go somewhere in order to get and bring back (someone or something)

He {it}picked up{/it} his dry cleaning.

dt: {bc}to let or put (people or things) into or onto a car, bus, ship, etc.

dt.t: She had a taxi {it}pick{/it} her {it}up{/it} at the airport and take her to the hotel.

dt: {bc}to make an area clean and organized by removing trash and putting things in the proper places

dt.t: We have just enough time to {it}pick up{/it} [={it}clean up{/it}] and wash our hands before dinner.

dt: {bc}to become busy usually after a period of little activity {bc}to improve or increase in activity

dt.t: Sales slowed down after the winter holidays, but we're expecting things to {it}pick up{/it} again this summer.

The economy/market seems to be {it}picking up{/it}.

dt: {bc}to begin again after a temporary stop

dt.t: The discussion {it}picked up{/it} this morning at the point where we had stopped yesterday.
After being separated for three years, they {phrase}picked up (right) where they left off{/phrase}.

dt: {bc}to start (something) again after a temporary stop

dt.t: We'll {it}pick up{/it} this discussion tomorrow.
Have you {it}picked up{/it} a copy of her new CD yet?

The team {it}picked up{/it} [={it}gained{/it}] a few yards on the last play.

dt: {bc}to become aware of (something, such as a story) and begin to write about it, work on it, etc.

dt.t: Few people had heard about this problem until the press {it}picked up{/it} [={it}took up{/it}] the story.

dt: {bc}to learn (something) usually in an informal way

dt: {bc}to become sick with (an illness) from someone or something

dt.t: I think I {it}picked up{/it} [={it}caught{/it}] a cold from someone at work.

dt: {bc}to be able to see, hear, or smell (something)

dt.t: This radio lets me {it}pick up{/it} stations from other countries.

dt: {bc}to meet and begin a usually brief sexual relationship with (someone)

dt.t: She used to go to bars to {it}pick up{/it} men.

dt: {bc}to use the power of the law to take and keep (someone, such as a criminal)

dt.t: The cops {it}picked up{/it} the suspect at a local bar.

dt: {bc}to make (someone) feel more energetic and lively

dt.t: I drank some coffee hoping that it would {it}pick{/it} me {it}up{/it} a little.

dt: {bc}to get (a player) from another team or from some other source

dt.t: The team {it}picked up{/it} three new players in the draft.

dt: {bc}to pay the money that is owed for something

dt.t: When she stays at expensive hotels during business trips, her company {it}picks up the tab{/it}.
They always offer to {it}pick up the check{/it} when we go out to dinner with them.

dt: {bc}to try to make a situation better after something bad has happened

dt.t: After her business went bankrupt, she {it}picked up the pieces{/it} and started again.

dt: {bc}to take (something, such as an idea) from another person or group and use it or continue to develop it yourself

dt.t: The media has recently begun to {it}pick up on{/it} this issue.

dt: {bc}to continue talking about (a statement, subject, etc.)

lbs: always followed by an adverb or preposition

dt.t: The horses slowly {it}pick their way{/it} across the rocky ground.

dt.t: I have a pain in my left {it}side{/it}.

dt: {bc}the place directly to the right or left of someone

dt.t: I stood {phrase}at/by her side{/phrase} as she spoke to reporters.
I was standing {phrase}on her left side{/phrase}.

dt: {bc}one of two or more opinions, positions, etc., that disagree with each other

dt.t: He listened to both {it}sides{/it} of the argument.

dt: {bc}one of the two or more people or groups that are involved in an argument, war, etc.

dt: {bc}a particular part or feature of something that is opposite to or different from another part or feature

dt: used in phrases like {phrase}on the large side{/phrase}, {phrase}on the heavy side{/phrase}, etc., to describe someone or something as somewhat heavy, large, etc.

dt: {bc}a part of someone's personality that is opposite or different from another part

dt: used in phrases like {phrase}be/get on someone's good/bad side{/phrase} and {phrase}be/get on the right/wrong side of someone{/phrase} to talk about doing things that cause someone to like you or dislike you

dt: {bc}included among the group of people who support a particular goal, project, etc.

dt: {bc}in addition to the main item in a meal

dt.t: We were served salmon with rice and grilled vegetables {it}on the side{/it}.

dt: {bc}served next to something rather than on top of it

dt.t: For my salad, I'd like Italian dressing {it}on the side{/it}.
She sells insurance {it}on the side{/it}.

dt: {bc}as part of a secret romantic relationship that is outside of your marriage or main romantic relationship

dt.t: a married man with a girlfriend {it}on the side{/it}
She had a fiancé but was seeing another man {it}on the side{/it}.

dros.drp: on the wrong/right side of the law

dt: used to say that someone is or is not living the life of a criminal

dt.t: He has been {it}on the wrong side of{/it} the law since he stole a car at the age of 17.
Now that she's out of prison she's trying to stay {it}on the right side of the law{/it}. [=trying not to get into trouble with the police]
He is not a very tall basketball player, but he does have quickness {it}on his side{/it}.
Luck seems to be {it}on your side{/it} tonight.
Time is {it}on our side{/it}. [=we have a lot of time to do what we need to do]

dt: {bc}next to each other and facing in the same direction

dt.t: We walked {it}side by side{/it} down the hallway.
They stood {it}side by side{/it} at the altar.

dt: {bc}together or very close to each other

dt.t: The tribes have lived peacefully {it}side by side{/it} for many years.
People worked {it}side by side{/it} to rescue the trapped coal miners.

dros.drp: the other side of the coin
the wrong side of the tracks

dt.t: Their actions were just {it}this side of{/it} illegal. [=were almost but not quite illegal]
the worst punishment {it}this side of{/it} death
She's not likely to be back {it}this side of{/it} Monday week.

dt: {bc}to a place that is on one side {bc}{sx|aside||}

dt.t: Please move/step {it}to the side{/it}. I need to get past you.
He put his luggage {it}to one side{/it}.
She took the boy {it}to the side{/it} [=away from other people] and told him to behave.

dt: {bc}in a state in which something is not dealt with, done, or used until a later time {bc}{sx|aside||}

dt.t: Let's put/leave that question {it}to the side{/it} for a moment.
He set his household chores {it}to the side{/it} to finish writing his essay.
They managed to put some money {it}to the side{/it} every month.

dros.drp: two sides of the same coin

shortdef: a place, space, or direction that is away from or beyond the center of something —often used with on or to
an outer surface or part of something —often + of
one of the surfaces of an object that is not the front, back, top, or bottom—often + of
